Riesling: pronounced aromas and flavours (ripe citrus and stone fruit)
similar to German Riesling but typically drier

represents only 4% of regional production but highest quality

Gewürztraminer: 100% varietal wines when grape listed on label

Gentil: must contain at least 50% noble grapes

Savagnin Rose: only grows in communes of Bourgheim, Gertwiller, Goxwiller, Heiligenstein and Obernai

Riesling: made in part with noble rot grapes
Gewürztraminer: made in part with noble rot grapes
Pinot gris: made in part with noble rot grapes
Muscat: made in part with noble rot grapes

Gewürztraminer: very sweet, similar to Tokaj Eszencia

Muscat: very sweet, similar to Tokaj Eszencia

Gamay: fruit flavors: raspberry, tart cherry, cranberry
other flavors: mushroom, forest floor, smoke, violet, baker's yeast, banana, bubblegum

Terroir: divided by Nizerand River with different soils on each side
granite and schist (decomposed rock) to the North
all Cru vineyards located on Northern side

Gamay: most villages located in the south
darker and more concentrated than regular Beaujolais
available in red and rosé styles
30 village names can appear on label
deeper and darker in color and character
notes of strawberry and black currant
Chardonnay: notes of pear, tropical fruits, and blanched almonds

Description: all in the north producing only red wines
more complex and known to age well
each has distinct personality - climate, soils, altitude, aspect

Gamay: 12 special climats can add their name to label
two styles: light, fruity, floral with violet and peach notes
bigger, spicier version that becomes more Pinot-like with age
aromas of strawberry, peach, violet and spicy cinnamon
smallest and rarest of the Crus
name refers to ancient oak forests
floral notes of rose and iris
nicknamed 'bouquet of flowers in a velvet basket'
decomposed pink granite and soft flaky quartz soils
most tannic and full-bodied wines of all Cru
young: plum, cherry and violet notes
aged up to 10 years: dried fruits, earthy truffles, meat and spice
higher altitude on steep slopes at foot of La Madone
great place to start for Beaujolais beginners
coolest Cru and last to start harvest
perfumed aromas of peaches and raspberry
Lily of the Valley and baking spices
granite soil so hard they had to bore holes in rock
six climats with slightly different styles
decomposed schist soil called 'roches pourries' (rotted rocks)
ripe cherry aromas from the soil
young: fleshy palate of peach, apricot, cherry, and plum
develops into earthy wine reminiscent of Burgundian Pinot Noir
aromatic peach, cherry, black currant, and raspberry flavor
more organic vineyards and winemakers than other Crus
known as 'Elegant Wine on the Hill'

silky mouthfeel and bright, refreshing acidity
named after Brulius, famous Roman lieutenant
one of original areas allowed to sell to Parisian market (1769)

exuberant fruity aromas of jammy plum and strawberry

Semi-Carbonic Maceration: whole clusters placed in vat without crushing
CO2 forces oxygen out of tank
responsible for banana, candied fruits, pear, raspberry and cranberry aromas

Sémillon / semillon: sweet wines made from grapes affected by botrytis

Chardonnay: oak or aging on lees is common
oak or aging on lees is common

Chenin blanc: sweeter made from extra-ripe or botrytis-affected grapes with stone fruit or tropical fruit aromas

Sauvignon blanc: tropical fruit flavours (passion fruit) and herbaceous notes (grass)

Sangiovese: very high tannins - must mature in oak

Corvina: pronounced flavours and dried fruit (prunes, raisins, figs)

Tempranillo: from simple fruity and light to powerful oak-aged

Grenache / Garnacha: old vines: the most powerful full-bodied

Albariño: Represents over 90% of all vines planted
Introduced by Cistercian monks in 12th century
Produces distinctive white wines adapted to Atlantic climate
Loureira blanca: Aromatic white variety contributing to blends
Treixadura: Traditional grape used in regional white wines
Godello: Quality white variety also found in other Galician regions
Caiño tinto: Native red grape variety part of traditional blends
Brancellao: Traditional red grape contributing to regional blends

Val do Salnés.Location: Lower reaches of river Umia, centered on Cambados
Val do Salnés.Landscape: Low undulating hills, vineyards on slopes and valley floors

O Rosal.Location: Along Portuguese frontier in basin of river Miño, from Atlantic coast to Tui
O Rosal.Landscape: Vineyards planted on terraces on banks of Miño

Condado do Tea.Location: From Tui eastwards along Miño valley to neighbouring Ribeiro
Condado do Tea.Landscape: More abrupt terrain with several small river valleys

Soutomaior.Location: South of Pontevedra city, incorporated into DO in 1996
Soutomaior.Soil: Light and sandy, covered with granite

Mencía: grown on steep terraced slopes called socalcos
Brancellao: contributes to regional red wine blends

Grüner Veltliner: Austria's most planted grape variety (32.6% of all vineyards)
citrus, stone fruit, and white pepper flavors
natural crossing of Savagnin (Traminer) and St. Georgener-Rebe
can range from simple to age-worthy examples
Riesling: very pure, mineral wines capable of long aging
pronounced aromas of lime, peach, blossom and petrol
Zweigelt: most widely planted red grape in Austria
cross of St. Laurent and Blaufränkisch
Blaufränkisch: second most important red grape
late-ripening variety producing red wines rich in tannin
deeply colored wines with dark fruit aromas
can be oaked or unoaked
ages well
Welschriesling: used for both still and sparkling wines
susceptible to noble rot for dessert wines
Pinot Noir: dry red wines similar to Burgundy

Terroir: diverse soil types: loess, limestone, schist, granite, volcanic
four main wine regions: Niederösterreich, Burgenland, Steiermark, Wien
DAC (Districtus Austriae Controllatus) system for regional wines

Grüner Veltliner: very pure, mineral wines capable of long aging
stands comparison with great wines of world

Blaufränkisch: grows well in region's slate-based soils

Description: known for both red wines and sweet wines

Terroir: challenging climate with high humidity during summer
vines kept 1.5-2 meters above ground for ventilation
horizontal trellises reduce typhoon wind damage
steep hillside plantings in mountainous regions for maximum sunlight
Italian ryegrass planted under vines to prevent soil erosion

Description: largest wine producing region (31% of domestic production)
birthplace of Japanese viticulture (718 AD in Katsunuma)
main wine region within Yamanashi Prefecture
cooler climate suitable for European varieties
recovery from bankruptcy through wine industry
